title: RS22581
content: The Securities Act of 1933 requires securities to be registered with the SEC before being offered to the public. The registration statement includes a prospectus for purchasers and Part II for additional information. Section 7 of the Act outlines the required information in the registration statement. The Securities Act of 1933 requires registration of securities with the SEC, including detailed information in the prospectus. Section 10(a) specifies required information, with exemptions for certain transactions and securities. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 focuses on disclosure to investors through periodic filings. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 mandates disclosure to the investing public through periodic reports filed with the SEC by issuers with securities traded on a national exchange or meeting certain asset and shareholder criteria. Registration under the Act requires detailed initial and ongoing filings, including annual and quarterly reports containing material information for investors. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires companies to disclose material information to investors through periodic reports filed with the SEC. Failure to disclose material information can lead to legal action under various provisions such as Section 18(a) and Rule 10b-5. The Investment Company Act of 1940 was enacted to regulate investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires investment companies to register with the SEC and file specified information to protect investors. It also restricts affiliations and interests of directors, officers, and employees. Registered investment companies must file reports and financial statements. The Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1984 increases sanctions against insider trading to deter violations and protect the integrity of securities markets. Insider trading refers to trading with material non-public information. Investment advisers must be registered with the SEC to provide advice on securities. The Insider Trading and Securities Fraud Enforcement Act of 1988 expanded penalties for insider trading, including civil penalties up to three times the profit gained or loss avoided. It also increased jail terms for criminal securities law violations and fines for individuals and corporations. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 addressed frivolous shareholder lawsuits, focusing on fraud, mismanagement, and nondisclosure of material information leading to shareholder losses. Some lawsuits were considered meritless, brought when stock value decreased. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) was enacted to address perceived failures of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA) in curbing abuses of securities fraud litigation. It limits shareholder lawsuits in federal courts by appointing a lead plaintiff, restricting individuals from leading multiple class actions, ensuring full disclosure of settlement terms, providing a safe harbor for forward-looking statements, enforcing proportionate liability, and requiring auditor disclosure of corporate fraud. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) was enacted to address failures of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA) in curbing securities fraud litigation abuses. SLUSA ensures securities fraud cases are brought only in federal courts under specific criteria, including involving a covered security and alleging misrepresentation or omission in connection with its purchase or sale. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 was prompted by the Enron Corporation's bankruptcy in 2002. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 was enacted in response to the Enron Corporation's bankruptcy and the WorldCom scandal. It established the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, imposed restrictions on accounting firms, required additional disclosures for public companies, and addressed issues such as securities fraud, management controls, penalties for violating securities laws, insider trading, and whistleblower protections. Dodd-Frank, a response to the financial crisis, made significant changes to financial regulation, affecting the securities industry. Title VII regulates the swaps markets, requiring collaboration between the CFTC and SEC. Title IX grants new powers to the SEC to enhance investor protections. Title IX of Dodd-Frank grants new powers to the SEC to increase investor influence and protection, including creating an Office of the Investor Advocate and a whistleblower bounty program. It also expands regulation of credit rating agencies, requires shareholder votes on executive compensation, sets requirements for proxy solicitation materials, and establishes a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. Additionally, it mandates disclosure of minerals from the Democratic Republic of the Congo benefiting armed groups. The STOCK Act prohibits insider trading by Members of Congress and employees, affirming a duty of trust. The JOBS Act aims to ease securities reporting requirements to support small businesses and startups, with a focus on emerging growth companies and crowdfunding. The JOBS Act supports emerging growth companies by allowing them to phase in SEC regulations and submit draft registration statements confidentially. Title III exempts certain companies from registration requirements if specific conditions are met, such as limits on the amount of securities sold to investors. To qualify for exemption under Title III of the JOBS Act, securities sold to investors must not exceed a maximum aggregate amount of $100,000 and must be sold through a funding portal.
